newsitem.title: PERU: Peru police seize record amount of drugs in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Peru police seize record amount of drugs in 1996.

text.p: Peruvian police said Monday they captured a record 171 tonnes of illegal drugs in 1996 -- nearly six times the 1995 haul of 29 tonnes.

The increase was mainly due to increased confiscation of marijuana, which soared to 150 tonnes in 1996 from six tonnes the previous year. Police also seized nearly 19 tonnes of cocaine paste, up from 15 tonnes in 1995.

In a year of heightened anti-narcotics activities, the police arrested 12,039 people on drug-related charges and destroyed 332 traffickers' installations including laboratories, landing strips and underground chambers.
This was up from 10,709 arrests and 285 destroyed installations in 1995.

Peru is the world's largest producer of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine, accounting for at least 50 percent of total production. But police say traffickers are increasingly diversifying away from cocaine to marijuana because of an official crackdown on coca leaf production.
Peru's economy receives $600 million a year from the illegal drugs trade, according to the government.
